entry.title: Combined summary - Compressed Bitcoin Transactions
entry.summary:
Recent advancements in Bitcoin transaction compression have led to the development of a Compressed Transaction Schema by Tom Briar and Andrew Poelstra, which can result in up to 30% size savings. This schema is relevant within the framework of BIP-324 and its details are available on GitHub. The updates to Bitcoin Core's reference implementation focus on excluding regenerable data such as valid signatures to optimize transaction sizes, this is particularly beneficial for Taproot keyspend transactions.
The Compressed Transaction Schema is designed for scenarios with restricted bandwidth but available computational resources for decompression, employing techniques like metadata packing, compact integers, compressed signatures with public key recovery, and substituting txid/vout pairs with block height and output index. Yet, challenges may arise during a block reorganization.
Tom Briar has highlighted new methods for handling lock time in transactions, aiming to minimize decompression time without compromising security, suggesting the omission of lock time grinding in favor of block height grinding. He also proposes encoding transaction outputs using a delta from a reference height, which is space-efficient when transmitting multiple transactions.
Further research includes empirical evaluation of these techniques using historical data and fuzz tests. A new RPC endpoint for compressing raw transactions is proposed, which will alert users about uncompressed TxId due to insufficient age. Discussions have also considered the use of a flattened index over all transactions per block, rather than a prefix tree for UTXO indexing, to maintain simplicity and space efficiency.
Fabian has acknowledged an oversimplification in his approach and suggests using a composite reference or a short hash as potential alternatives, though he admits Tom's scheme might already be optimally efficient. Fabian's own alternative involves an indexed sorted set of UTXOs, which could save space and support data pruning techniques, but further investigation into this idea is required.
Andrew Poelstra has requested Tom Briar to produce a chart demonstrating the application's compression strength, focusing on "optimum" transactions like 2-in-2-out wpkh and Taproot transactions, and considering data for less common transaction types. Tom Briar's contributions to bitcoin transaction compression continue through active development and collaboration, ensuring efficient transmission and integrity of transactions.
